Moses also determined the time of gathering to be when the sun was a spear's length high, a time that was already quite bright with the light of the risen sun, so that all the spectators could witness and see the competition clearly.
text.60:
In this verse, Allah explains that an agreement was reached between Moses and Pharaoh regarding the place, day, and time of the competition. Pharaoh then left the debate to arrange his deception. The magicians were gathered, their equipment perfected, their supporters and assistants, and others, were prepared. On the day that had been agreed upon, which was the festival of Syam an-Nasim, Pharaoh departed with his entourage to the place he had agreed upon with Moses. He sat on his throne, accompanied by his top officials, flanked by his people on his left and right. Not long after, Moses arrived with his staff, accompanied by his brother Aaron. Pharaoh galvanized his magicians, who stood in neat rows before him, expecting them to carry out their task, to demonstrate their skills in the best possible way, promising to fulfill all their requests if they won, as explained in Allah's word:

And the magicians came to Pharaoh. They said, "Is there surely a reward for us if we are the winners?" He (Pharaoh) said, "Yes, and you will surely be among those brought near [to me]." (al-A'raf/7: 113 and 114)
text.61:
When Moses confronted Pharaoh's magicians, Moses warned them not to follow Pharaoh's call, to fabricate lies against Allah, saying things that are not true about Him, such as considering the miracle he brought as magic, when in fact it was one of His greatness and power. If you hold such a view like Pharaoh, Allah will punish you, wiping out your descendants so that none remain, as a recompense for your misguided actions. Allah says:

Allah will repay all that they have fabricated. (al-An'am/6: 138)

Those who fabricate lies against Allah are the losers. They will not prosper in their endeavors, nor will they achieve their goals, because they are the most unjust, as Allah says:

And who is more unjust than one who invents about Allah a lie or denies His verses? Indeed, the wrongdoers will not succeed. (al-An'am/6: 21)

Therefore, be aware and repent. Abandon the act of fabricating lies against Allah. Leave the misguided path you are taking, so that you may be saved from the torment that will be inflicted upon those who fabricate lies against Allah. They are people who have gone astray in this world, yet they still think that their actions are good and right.
text.62: After Pharaoh's magicians heard Moses' warning and threat, they became confused, each with their own different responses. Then they held a special meeting, exchanging ideas about what they should do. Their conversation was kept very secret so that it wouldn't leak. Indeed, that is generally the case; a meeting is held to find tactics to defeat the opponent, and the conversation and decisions of the meeting must be kept secret, lest the opponent find out. The same was true of Pharaoh's magicians, because they were worried that if their conversation was heard and known by Moses and Aaron, then the two of them would make preparations and acquire sufficiently strong equipment to face their magic, which would be difficult to defeat.
text.63:
Among their secret conversations that could be recorded was that if what Moses presented later was truly magic, they would clearly defeat him. But if what he presented was a miracle from Allah, they might not be able to defeat him. "If he defeats us in the competition later, there's nothing we can do, we'll just surrender and follow him." Finally, they agreed to say that Moses and Aaron were very clever magicians who would drive them out of their land with their magic and would remove their noble position.

They deliberately formulated a formula that contained these three factors that could lead to Moses and Aaron being hated and losing their influence. However, common sense and sound thinking would not accept the reasons of the magicians, people who wanted to violate someone's human rights by expelling them from their homes, as well as people who would eliminate their position.
text.64:
According to Pharaoh's magicians, Moses and Aaron were magicians who wanted to expel them from their homeland and seize power. Therefore, to face this threatening danger, they worked together, shoulder to shoulder, gathering all their strength, devising all strategies and tricks, and demonstrating all their intelligence on the day of the competition. In this way, it would be easy for them to defeat the magic of Moses and his brother Aaron. How happy they would be on that day if victory were on their side. Allah says:

So when the magicians came, they said to Pharaoh, "Is there surely a reward for us if we are the victors?" He (Pharaoh) answered, "Yes, and indeed, you will then be of those near [to me]." (ash-Shu'ara/26: 41 and 42)
text.65:
In this verse, Allah explains that after Pharaoh's magicians felt they had sufficient preparation, that all their provisions were complete, they came to the designated competition place in neat rows. After they faced Moses, they gave Moses the choice: should Moses throw his staff first? Or should the magicians throw theirs first? This action of the magicians was a wisdom that manifested good manners and their humility towards Moses, as if they had received inspiration from Allah. Moses, after thinking for a moment, then chose for them to throw their staffs first, with the consideration that if the magicians had demonstrated their magic with sincerity and ability, at that time Allah would show His power, by making the truth victorious over falsehood, making the miracle victorious over magic, and the false magic would disappear. In accordance with Allah's word:

"Nay, We hurl the Truth against falsehood, and it knocks out its brain, and behold, falsehood vanishes!" (al-Anbiya'/21: 18)
text.66:
In this verse, Allah explains that after Moses made his choice, he said to Pharaoh's magicians, "You are the ones to begin first, so that we can see your magic, and know what you are actually doing." After that, they threw their ropes and staffs, saying, "By the glory of Pharaoh, surely we are the ones who will win."

Unexpectedly, suddenly the ropes and staffs that they threw, were seen by Moses as if they were crawling quickly, appearing as snakes moving swiftly back and forth.
text.67:
This time, Pharaoh's magicians demonstrated their extraordinary magic, causing Moses to feel fear in his heart upon seeing the event. It wasn't just Moses who felt fear, but the audience as well, because their eyes had been bewitched by that extraordinary magic, as Allah says:

"So when they had thrown, they bewitched the eyes of the people and struck terror into them, and they presented a great [and impressive] magic." (al-A'raf/7: 116)
text.68: In this verse, it is explained that Allah comforts Musa. He said to Musa, "O Musa! Do not fear or worry, calm your heart and tranquilize your mind, do not be influenced by their magic. It is not the reality, but only an illusion. You are the one who will be superior and victorious later in this competition. They will be defeated and helpless."
text.69:
After that, Allah commanded Musa to throw the staff that was in his right hand. Musa immediately carried out the command. By the power and will of Allah, Musa's staff became a large snake and swallowed all that was made by Pharaoh's magicians, namely the ropes and staffs that appeared like moving snakes. In reality, what they did was merely an illusion and only the trickery of the magicians, as a result of disciplined and lengthy training, completely without substance and would not last long. In any case, the magician will not win with his deceptive magic. Such a thing is a sinful act, and those who commit sin will not prosper. As Allah says:

Indeed, the criminals will never succeed. (Yunus/10: 17)
text.70: In this verse, it is narrated that after Moses threw the staff in his right hand, it became a large serpent and swallowed all that the Pharaoh's magicians had done. After witnessing the magnificence of the event, and realizing that what Moses had done was not magic, but a miracle, not originating from the magical arts they knew, nor a trick they recognized, and that it was an undeniable truth, and that no one could do such a thing except the One who possesses power, who, when He wills something, simply says, "Be," and it is; the Pharaoh's magicians immediately prostrated themselves, declaring that they had believed in the Lord of all the worlds. The Lord of Moses and Aaron.
text.71:
In this verse, Allah explains that Pharaoh, after learning that his magicians had surrendered and believed in the Lord of Moses and Aaron, was very angry with them because they had committed two major errors. First, they rashly believed in Moses before thinking deeply and before obtaining permission from him. Second, because he suspected that they were Moses' students in magic, they had agreed to show his weakness, in order to make Moses' da'wah stronger and more acceptable to the people, so Pharaoh felt his affairs were seen as getting bigger and more impressive.

To prevent the magicians from being followed by the masses in the future, Pharaoh threatened to cut off their hands and feet alternately, so that they could no longer do anything. Pharaoh also threatened to crucify them on the trunks of palm trees. Pharaoh threatened severe punishment to his magicians who had believed in Moses, so that the magicians would compare his punishment with the punishment of the Lord of Moses, who did not cut off hands and feet alternately, so that they would return to their original beliefs and abandon their belief in Moses, because Pharaoh suspected that his magicians believed in Moses only because they were afraid of the painful and prolonged punishment and torment of the Lord of Moses.
text.72: This verse explains that Pharaoh's threat was ignored by the magicians who had believed in Moses, and it had no effect on them whatsoever. They would not return to embracing misguided beliefs, but they would remain steadfast in their faith in Moses based on clear evidence, namely the miracle they witnessed in Moses' staff, which came from Allah, the Lord who created them. They would not waver or shift from the belief they now held, no matter what Pharaoh did to them. They maintained that even if Pharaoh could carry out his threat, it would only be in this world, because Pharaoh could only commit his cruelty and injustice in this fleeting world. However, they prioritized and hoped for a pleasing reward in the Hereafter, a place that is eternal and everlasting.
text.73: Pharaoh's magicians were completely determined to believe in Allah, the Lord of all the worlds, the Lord who had done so much good for them throughout their lives. Whatever would happen, whatever would befall them, they hoped that Allah would forgive all the mistakes and sins they had committed, especially the sin of magic that Pharaoh had ordered them to perform. This verse is concluded with an affirmation that Allah is the best rewarder for those who are obedient to His commands, and His punishment is more painful and eternal for those who commit disobedience, violate His commands, and also as an answer to Pharaoh's statement, "Surely you will know which of us is more severe in punishment and more lasting."
text.74:
In this verse, Allah explains that whoever comes to their Lord in the Hereafter in a state of sin, because in the world they disbelieved, refused to believe in the verses of Allah, and committed many sins, abandoning Allah's commands and violating His prohibitions, they will be cast into Hell. They will not die in it and will be continuously punished without end. In line with this verse, Allah says:

"And those who disbelieve - for them is the fire of Hell. [Death] will not be decreed for them so they may die, nor will its torment be lightened for them." (Fathir/35: 36)

And His saying:

"And the most wretched one will avoid it, [He] who will [enter and] be burned in the greatest Fire, Then he will neither die therein nor live." (al-A'la/87: 11-12 and 13)
text.75:
On the contrary, in this verse, Allah explains that whoever comes to their Lord on the Day of Judgment in a state of believing in Allah and in what His messengers brought, such as miracles and other things, and has done righteous deeds sincerely and earnestly, they will obtain a high and noble place, due to their faith and righteous deeds. Each person in the Hereafter will obtain a degree according to their deeds, as explained in Allah's word:

And for all there are degrees [of reward and punishment] for what they have done, and your Lord is not unaware of what they do. (al-An'am/6: 132)
text.76:
In this verse, Allah explains that what is meant by the high and noble place is Jannatu 'Adn, which is the Garden of perpetual residence. In the Garden flow rivers, containing things such as khamar, honey, milk, and water, and its inhabitants will abide therein forever. Such is the reward for those who are cleansed from disbelief and disobedience. How fortunate they are, as Allah says:

"Successful indeed are those who purify themselves." (al-A'la/87: 14)
text.77:
In this verse, Allah explains that there were no signs that Pharaoh would accept the reasons and evidence presented to him; he remained in his arrogance and pride. Allah revealed to Prophet Musa (Moses) to leave Egypt, Pharaoh's land, at night so that he would not be seen by Pharaoh and his soldiers, along with Allah's servants whom he was sent to save from Pharaoh's tyranny. Musa and the Children of Israel left Egypt. When they reached the edge of the Red Sea, the Children of Israel said to Musa, "O Musa, Pharaoh and his soldiers are pursuing us from behind, and in front of us is a vast ocean. What should we do to cross that ocean?"

Allah commanded Musa to strike the sea with his staff. After Musa carried out this command, the sea split open all the way to the other side. The number of splits in the sea corresponded to the number of tribes among the Children of Israel, which was twelve, and they became dry paths in the middle of the sea, neither muddy nor watery. Between the splits, the water stood upright like great mountains. Each tribe passed through only one path. They could see each other, one tribe could see the other. Musa and the Children of Israel walked through their respective paths with a feeling of security, not worried about being overtaken by Pharaoh and his soldiers, and not afraid of drowning, until they reached the other side of the sea safely, as mentioned in Allah's words:

"Then We inspired Moses, "Strike the sea with your staff," and it parted, and each portion was like a great towering mountain." (ash-Shu'ara/26: 63)

And His words:

"Then We saved Moses and all those with him." (ash-Shu'ara/26: 65)
text.78:
In this verse, Allah explains that after Pharaoh learned of Moses' departure with the Children of Israel from Egypt, he sent people to the cities to gather his army with the intention of pursuing Moses and his group. Pharaoh was very angry, so he ordered his army to chase Moses and his people, because they were considered to have always done things that caused him anger. As Allah says:

Then Pharaoh sent (messengers) to the cities to gather (his army). (Pharaoh said), "Indeed, those (Children of Israel) are only a small band, and indeed, they have done things that provoke our anger." (ash-Syu'ara/26: 53-54 and 55)

After that, Pharaoh and his army immediately pursued Moses and his group. After arriving at the edge of the sea and seeing many paths stretched out before them, without the slightest suspicion, they passed through the paths that Moses and his group had taken, because they thought it was an ordinary road. After Pharaoh and his army were in the middle of the sea, while Moses and his group had reached the other side and landed safely, suddenly the sea water reunited, closing in on Pharaoh and his army, so they all drowned. Before drowning, and when he saw the dangerous situation and that it was impossible to save himself from the danger of drowning, Pharaoh finally realized and uttered words that showed that he acknowledged and believed that there is no god but the God believed in by the Children of Israel, and that he was one of those who submitted to Allah. Pharaoh's confession was no longer useful, because he had committed a great sin and caused destruction on earth. Pharaoh died drowning, but his body was saved to be evidence of Allah's power for future generations, as Allah says:

Until when Pharaoh was about to drown, he said, "I believe that there is no god except the God in whom the Children of Israel believe, and I am among those who submit (to Him)." Now? And you had disobeyed [Him] before and were of the corrupters. So today We will save your body that you may be a sign to those after you. And indeed, many among the people, of Our signs, are heedless. (Yunus/10: 90-91 and 92)
text.79: This verse explains that Pharaoh had misled his people. He assumed that Moses and the Children of Israel would not be able to escape his pursuit because the sea stretched wide before them. After they reached the shore, he pretended as if it was due to his greatness that the sea split, forming pathways, so he invited his army to enter those pathways until they all eventually drowned. Pharaoh received no guidance whatsoever to avoid the danger of drowning, so he and his army perished.
text.80:
This verse explains that Allah has bestowed upon the Children of Israel three kinds of blessings.

1. They were saved by Him from the cruelty of their enemy, namely Pharaoh and his people. When Pharaoh inflicted upon the Children of Israel the severest of punishments, they slaughtered the male children and spared the female children, and when Allah drowned Pharaoh and his army while Musa was watching. As Allah says:

And (remember) when We saved you from the people of Pharaoh, who were afflicting you with the worst torment, slaughtering your sons and letting your women live. And in that was a great trial from your Lord. And (remember) when We parted the sea for you, so We saved you and drowned the people of Pharaoh while you were looking on. (al-Baqarah/2: 49 and 50)

2. Musa spoke directly with his Lord on the right side of Mount Sinai, and Allah revealed the Torah to him, which clearly details His law.

3. They were granted Mann, which is food like honey, very sweet in taste, white in color like ice, and Salwa, which is a type of quail bird with delicious meat, when they were lost in a vast wilderness. This food was available from dawn until sunrise.
text.81: In this verse, Allah commands them to eat from the good sustenance, which is delicious in taste and which Allah has bestowed upon them. They should never misuse it, such as spending it wastefully, not being grateful for it, donating it to acts of disobedience, and so on. Because if they do so, it means they have invited the wrath of Allah, which will inflict His punishment. Woe and destruction be upon those who have been afflicted by the wrath of Allah.
text.82:
In this verse, Allah affirms that He is the Most Forgiving for those who repent from the act of shirk, purify themselves from sin, are sincere and perform their deeds solely for the sake of Allah, fulfill His obligations, avoid disobedience, are steadfast in their worship until they die, and fulfill Allah's commands, as explained in His word:

And worship your Lord until there comes to you the certainty (death). (al-Hijr/15: 99)
text.83:
Allah rebuked Musa because he hastened to ascend the mountain and left his people below, even though Allah had commanded him to ascend the hill together with his people to receive a portion of the Torah in the form of tablets and scrolls. In truth, he was very eager to converse intimately with his Lord to receive the tablets of the Torah. Because of this intense desire, he departed without taking his people, ascending the hill alone. He left his people below and instructed Harun to guard and watch over them during his absence. Upon arriving at the top of the hill, he concentrated his soul and mind, eagerly awaiting what his Lord would reveal to him as He had promised. Suddenly, Allah spoke, questioning him with a tone of rebuke or reproach. Why did he hasten to ascend the hill alone without bringing his people with him, even though he had been commanded to come with them?

Indeed, Allah's rebuke was appropriate for his mistake, because in addition to not fully carrying out Allah's command, Musa had left his people without leadership, even though his brother Harun would watch over them. It was as if Musa, driven by a strong desire to converse intimately with his Lord, had relinquished his responsibility towards his people and no longer cared what would happen to them during his absence. For a Prophet entrusted by Allah to lead and watch over his people, this is a negligence or disregard of his primary duty that is regrettable, and he deserved to receive a rebuke or reproach from his Lord.
text.84: Moses answered his Lord's rebuke by saying that his people were behind him and the distance between him and his people was not so far. If he preceded in ascending this mountain by a few steps, it was not with the intention of abandoning them, and if they were called, they would surely be able to gather with him in a short time. Indeed, he hastened to climb this hill because he wanted to carry out Allah's command immediately, precisely at the appointed time, which was after he and his people had been around Mount Tur for 40 nights. He came in haste because he wanted to quickly obtain Allah's pleasure (ridha). It was because of this strong desire to achieve His pleasure that he became negligent and oblivious to Allah's command to come together with them.
text.85:
This verse explains that after Moses left his people to converse with his Lord, his people deviated from the religion of Tawhid and worshipped the calf idol made by al-Samiri. Indeed, Allah intended to test the faith of the people of Moses, whether they truly had a strong and resilient faith, or whether there were still traces of shirk or belief in idol worship in their hearts and souls. It turned out that their faith was not yet so strong and deep, because only a few days after Moses left them, and while still under the supervision of Aaron, they were easily deceived and fell into the trap of al-Samiri, who came from a people who worshipped cows. However, Allah will not simply allow or accept it if humans declare themselves believers without being tested first, according to His word:

"Do people think that they will be left alone because they say, "We have believed," and will not be tested? And We have already tested those before them, and Allah will surely make evident those who are truthful, and He will surely make evident those who are liars." (al-'Ankabut/29: 2 and 3)

It turned out that the people of Moses were not among those whose faith was strong and deep, because only a short time after Moses left them (according to a narration, only 20 days), they abandoned the religion of Tawhid and returned to the religion of idol worshippers. This is not regrettable and is very likely to happen because they had long been under the rule of Pharaoh. Therefore, their mentality was damaged and their morals became weak, so loyalty and patience in upholding a principle could not be expected from them. So al-Samiri easily deceived them by making a statue in the shape of a golden calf that could make a sound like the sound of a calf, so they were attracted to al-Samiri's words that this was the real God. As for the God of Moses and Aaron who cannot be seen, why should we worship Him?
text.86:
Hearing the word of his Lord explaining that his people had been led astray by Samiri, he quickly returned to his people in a state of great annoyance and anger. He found his people kneeling before a golden calf statue, worshiping and adoring it. They said among themselves, "This is our god and also the god of Musa. Indeed, Musa has forgotten, so he went to meet his Lord on the mountaintop, while his Lord is here." It is impossible to describe how saddened Musa was to see his people so quickly and easily led astray by Samiri, and how great the anger in his chest was seeing the atmosphere and condition of his people.

According to one narration, after seeing his people worshiping idols, he then heard a commotion and various kinds of shouts from his people and saw them dancing around the statue. Qurtubi narrates that Abu Bakar ath-Turthusy was once asked about a group of people performing dhikr mentioning the name of Allah and sending blessings mentioning the name of Prophet Muhammad by dancing and beating drums, and because they were so engrossed, some of them fainted, then they took the food they had brought and prepared, what is the ruling on their actions? Is it permitted by Islam or not? ath-Turthusy replied, "The Sufi school of thought, that kind of thing is false, an ignorance and misguidance. Islam is the (teaching of) the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Messenger. As for beating drums (and dancing) until like someone possessed, then the first person to initiate it was Samiri when he made the calf statue for the people of Musa to worship by dancing around it. So, such an act is the act of disbelievers and calf worshipers."

Furthermore, Musa said to his people, "Why do you worship that statue when Allah has promised you good and beneficial promises after bestowing upon you various blessings such as freeing you from the people of Pharaoh, placing you in this place, giving you delicious and nutritious food. Allah promised to send down Al-Kitab to you, in which there are sharia and regulations for your good and happiness in this world and the hereafter. He also promised to give you many rewards if you remain faithful and do good deeds and promised that you would enter the holy land of Palestine by defeating its strong and mighty inhabitants. Why did you turn away from the religion of Allah so quickly when it hasn't been long since that promise was declared by Allah to you, and the signs of that promise will surely be realized and fulfilled as you have seen and experienced yourselves? Do you think that you have been waiting a long time for the realization of that promise, or are you deliberately waiting for the wrath of Allah upon you with this act? Didn't you promise me that you would remain faithful until I returned to you, and would not create anything that would damage your aqidah or contradict that aqidah."
text.87: His people answered, "We did not break the promise of our own will and desire, because we could not control ourselves. If we had been left to our own will, we certainly would not have done this. But As-Samiri had deceived us, the foolish ones, so that we were attracted by his words and his captivating persuasion. As-Samiri had forced us to carry a heavy burden consisting of jewelry that he borrowed from the Egyptians when we were about to leave Egypt. He said that there would be a celebration later, because the jewelry had to be brought and we were ordered to carry it. He hid this from you, O Musa, because he was afraid of being forbidden to bring it. After you left, he ordered us to dig a large hole in the ground and light a fire to burn the jewelry, so we threw all the jewelry we were carrying."
text.88: Then, As-Samiri brought out from the pit a lump of gold in the shape of a calf, and it produced a sound like the sound of a calf. Indeed, As-Samiri was skilled; and he was able to make pipes within the statue so that when the wind blew, the sound of a calf would come out. As-Samiri said to us that this was the true god, the god of all of us, and also the god of Moses, whom we should worship and adore, and to whom we should make requests when we desire or need something. As-Samiri also said that Moses had gone up the mountain to meet God, while the God Moses was going to meet was right here. Indeed, Moses was very forgetful, so he went to great lengths to search for something in a faraway place, while what he was looking for was right here.
text.89: In this verse, Allah explains how foolish the people of Moses were because they could not consider something carefully, whether it was bad or good, acceptable to reason, or impossible. Did they not notice that the idol was a lifeless object, powerless, unable to speak, and unable to answer questions, let alone provide help or ward off danger? Whereas a real cow, which is alive, moves on its own, can gore and kick, can lift things or pull carts, no sane person would want to worship it. Yet, they accepted and were willing to be ordered to worship the calf idol, which was a lifeless object.
text.90: Harun had given advice and warnings to them when he saw his people turn away from worshipping Allah to worshipping idols and holding religious ceremonies that contradicted the tauhid they had adhered to all this time and promised Musa that they would continue to worship Allah until he returned to them from Mount Tur. Harun said to them, "O my people, indeed you have been tested in your faith with the calf idol. Are you truly believers and firmly adhere to your religion, so that it cannot be doubted by any persuasion, or is your faith only lip service, so that when something attracts your attention or deceives you, you abandon your true religion and belief? Your Lord is truly the Most Compassionate, the Most Creator, Who created everything whose proof of mercy and love can be seen in the universe and can be felt by His creatures. He has bestowed upon you physical and spiritual perfection and given you sharia and regulations that guarantee your safety and happiness in this world and the hereafter. He has bestowed upon you the blessing of faith and freed you from the cruelty and brutality of Pharaoh. Why can you now be deceived and tricked by Samiri with a golden statue in the form of a calf that makes a sound like a real calf? You have truly deviated from the right path and have broken your promise with my brother Musa when he was about to ascend the mountain to receive the tablets of the Torah as guidance from your Lord. Abandon worshipping the idol that cannot provide benefit or ward off harm, and return to the religion of tauhid and repent, surely Allah will accept your repentance and forgive your mistakes because He is the Most Forgiving and Most Merciful. Follow my advice and my call so that you may become servants of Allah who are pleasing to Him."
text.91: All of Harun's advice, even though presented gently and with arguments and reasons acceptable to reason, did not receive a good response among them. They were more attracted to the enticements and deceptions of the Samiri. They said to Harun, "We will continue to worship the idol until Musa returns to us, and he is the one who will decide whether we are in error and deviation, or whether the idol we worship is merely the deception of the Samiri."
text.92: Moses deeply regretted Aaron's lack of decisive action against the transgressions of his people. Why did he only rebuke and advise his people, when worshipping idols is *shirk* (polytheism) that cannot be forgiven, and cannot be tolerated regardless of the reasons put forward by his people? Why didn't he follow Moses with the believers to inform him of this and take a firm stance against the disobedient ones? If Aaron had taken such action, surely his disbelieving people would have been afraid and perhaps would have abandoned the worship of the idol for fear of losing the leader they loved.
text.93: Moses retorted to Aaron with somewhat harsh words, "Have you disobeyed and violated my command? I entrusted you to take my place after I left, to act and prevent following the path of those who want to cause corruption." The author of the *tafsir* Al-Kasysyaf explains this as follows, "Moses was a stern person and sometimes acted harshly regarding matters related to the rights of Allah and religion. Therefore, he could not control himself when he saw his people had deviated from the religion of *tawhid*, so he threw down the tablets of the Torah that he was carrying because he was shocked and astonished to see his people's deviation. He rebuked and scolded his brother Aaron while pulling his hair and beard as if his brother was his enemy, not his brother and helper."
text.94: This verse explains that Aaron, a man of calm and gentle nature, did not respond to his brother's harsh and coarse words with harshness and coarseness as well. Instead, he calmly said to Moses, "O son of my mother, do not seize me by my beard and my head. Indeed, I did not take firm action as you desired because if I had acted in that way, they would have been divided into two groups: the believers and the rebels. Enmity would have arisen, and perhaps war between the two groups. If this had happened, you would have blamed me as well, accusing me of dividing the Children of Israel. Therefore, we took a cautious approach while waiting for your return from the mountain."
text.95: In this verse, Allah explains that Moses rebuked Samiri with the question, "Why did you commit this despicable and God-detested act, causing some of the Children of Israel to become disbelievers after having faith and worshipping the idol that you deliberately made for them? You have corrupted the true creed of my people and led them astray. Do you know the consequences of your abominable deed?"
text.96: Samiri answered Musa's scolding and rebukes. "I knew something that your people did not know, so I made a statue from the gold brought from Egypt in the shape of a calf, and I made the statue as beautiful as possible to attract their attention. That was my opinion, and that action was the best according to my thinking." According to some Mufasirin, Samiri answered Musa's scolding with a strange answer that could leave the impression as if he had also received revelation from God and had been in contact with Jibril and knew him. Samiri said that he burned the gold they brought from Egypt in a hole they made themselves, and he took a handful of soil from the footprint of Jibril, and then something resembling a calf came out of the hole. Thus, some of the Children of Israel were attracted to Samiri's persuasion and deception to worship the calf-shaped statue. Because the calf statue was not just any statue, but had truly been sent by Allah to be worshipped and praised.
text.97:
Moses said to al-Samiri, "Go away from here, you have no right to associate with anyone, and no one is allowed to associate with you. If anyone asks you about your condition, you must answer, 'I am not allowed to approach anyone, and no one is allowed to approach me.'" This was Moses' very harsh and firm action towards him. Where would al-Samiri go? There was no place to live because the surrounding area was only a vast and barren desert, not a single piece of land in the Sahara desert that could be inhabited by humans. Even wild and ferocious animals would find it difficult and suffer to live in that endless desert. It is narrated that after being expelled by Moses, al-Samiri left the place without knowing where he was going or what his destination would be. He ventured into the vast Sahara desert and found nothing but wild and ferocious animals. Thus, what Moses said to him was proven: if he met someone who asked about him, he should answer "La misasa."

Even though he never uttered the words "La misasa," in practice, his experience venturing into the desert was as if he himself was shouting those words, so that no one dared to approach him. Then Moses uttered words of farewell to him, that he would face a day that could not be avoided, namely the Day of Judgment, the Day of Recompense, where he would receive retribution for his deeds commensurate with the magnitude of the sin he had committed. Then Moses ordered al-Samiri to turn to the god he had made, which he worshipped and praised, and said, "I will crush this idol until it becomes dust, and I will scatter its dust into the sea so that it disappears without a trace."
text.98:
In this verse, Moses states that the idol is not God, their God is the One and Only God. There is no God but Allah. He is the only one worthy of worship and glorification, and to Him alone are all prayers and requests made. All creatures are dependent on Him because He is the All-Creator and All-Powerful. His knowledge is vast and limitless, encompassing everything. Nothing escapes His knowledge, whether on earth, in the heavens, or in between, in accordance with His saying:

"Not absent from Him is an atom's weight within the heavens or within the earth or [what is] smaller than that or greater, but that it is in a clear Register (Lauh Mahfudz)," (Saba'/34: 3)
text.99:
In this verse, Allah explains to Prophet Muhammad (saw) that the stories narrated in the previous verses, such as the story of Moses with Pharaoh and the Samiri, as well as the stories of previous prophets, should serve as examples for him in facing his people who are very disbelieving and disobedient. Indeed, this is the situation of every messenger, even though books and miracles have been revealed to them to declare the truth of their da'wah, their people still disbelieve and strive with all their might to oppose their call and continue to be hostile, even wanting to kill them to eliminate them so that the voice of truth they convey is no longer heard.

Just as Allah revealed the Zabur to Prophet David (a.s.), the Torah to Prophet Moses (a.s.), and the Gospel to Prophet Jesus (a.s.), Allah has revealed the Al-Qur'an to Muhammad, a Book that they should receive well because the teachings contained within it are for their benefit and happiness in this world and the hereafter. The Al-Qur'an is a complete holy Book containing various guidelines on laws, social interactions, economics, morality, and so on. In addition, the Al-Qur'an is the greatest miracle for the Prophet. No one can match the beauty of its language and the height of its literature. Therefore, the Prophet should be patient and never despair or grieve, continue to struggle until victory is achieved and all falsehood disappears from the face of the earth, and there is nothing worthy of worship except Allah, the One and Only, the All-Powerful.
text.100: Whoever turns away from the teachings of the Qur'an, even though it is clear to him that it is a revelation from Allah and its truth cannot be denied, then his rejection of those teachings is solely because of following his own desires, or because of fear of losing influence, position, and so on. People like that are rightly considered stubborn, misguided, and unwilling to accept the truth. Therefore, Allah will not forgive them, and on the Day of Judgment, they will bear the burden of their denial and arrogance, the greatest and heaviest of sins, almost unbearable for them to carry. They will be thrown into Hell, where they will abide forever, and inflicted with a most painful torment according to their denial and disobedience. How heavy is the burden they bear, and how painful is the punishment they receive.
text.101: Whoever turns away from the teachings of the Qur'an, even though it is clear to him that it is a revelation from Allah and its truth cannot be denied, then his rejection of those teachings is solely because of following his desires, or because of fear of losing influence, position, and so on. Such people are rightly considered stubborn, misguided, and unwilling to accept the truth. Therefore, Allah will not forgive them, and on the Day of Judgment, they will bear the burden of their denial and arrogance, a sin that is the greatest and heaviest, and almost impossible for them to bear. They will be thrown into Hell, where they will abide forever, and be afflicted with a most painful torment according to their denial and disobedience. How heavy is the burden they bear, and how painful is the punishment they receive.
text.102: That will occur on the Day of Resurrection, specifically at the time of the second blowing of the trumpet as a sign for all humanity to gather in the Plain of Gathering (Mahsyar) to receive the reckoning of their deeds and efforts while they were still in the world. Good deeds will be rewarded with manifold rewards, and evil deeds will be recompensed with a fitting punishment. On that day, Allah will gather the sinners while their faces are pale and blue, due to the severity of the suffering they feel and the terrible and dreadful atmosphere at that time, especially after contemplating the misfortune that befalls them, why they did not accept the truth in the past and continued to indulge their desires and the will of Satan.
text.103: They whispered to each other and asked each other in voices that were almost inaudible because they felt so afraid and worried. "Have we only lived in this world for ten days? Why have we been gathered in the Mahsyar field when we haven't had even a little opportunity to do good deeds and prepare ourselves to face this day?" Indeed, that is how it is with everyone who is struck by a severe disaster, the twists and turns of their past life are reflected in their minds, all passing by very quickly, as if the life they enjoyed for decades happened only in a few moments.
text.104:
In this verse, Allah affirms that He knows all that they discuss in whispers, when the most intelligent among them says that they only stayed on earth for one day. Perhaps the intention is to say only one day so that they are freed from the torment of their disobedience and from the recompense of their deeds because they only lived in the world for a short time, not given a longer opportunity to repent and do good deeds. But there is no point in discussing such things anymore, because in reality they were given ample opportunity during their lifetime in the world to return to the truth, but they did not use that opportunity at all. In another verse, Allah explains their condition, namely:

"And the Day the Hour appears the criminals will swear they had not remained [in the grave] except an hour." (ar-Rum/30: 55)

And His word:

"And on the Day He will gather them, [it will be] as if they had not remained [in the world] but an hour of a day, [during which] they will recognize one another. Those will have lost who denied the meeting with Allah and were not guided." (Yunus/10: 45)
text.105:
In this verse, Allah explains, as an answer to the questions of the polytheists to Muhammad SAW, that the mountains on the Day of Judgment will be pulverized and scattered in the air, like dust carried by the wind everywhere, leaving no trace whatsoever. With the discovery of the atomic bomb in the twentieth century, one can imagine how terrible and devastating the destruction and annihilation will be on the Day of Judgment. Even a single atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, which is considered small in its explosive power compared to the explosive power of nuclear bombs today, caused such tremendous destruction. How much more so the destruction that will occur on the Day of Judgment, which will certainly be thousands of times greater and more devastating than the destruction caused by the atomic bombs in Hiroshima and Nagasaki. In another verse, Allah also explains the state of the mountains on the Day of Judgment, His word:

"And (on) the Day the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will be terrified except whom Allah wills. And all will come to Him humbled. And you see the mountains, thinking them firmly fixed, while they pass as the passing of clouds. [It is] the work of Allah, who perfected all things. Indeed, He is Acquainted with that which you do." (an-Naml/27: 87 and 88)
text.106:
After the mountains are crushed and scattered by the wind everywhere, the places where the mountains stood become level, and the face of the earth, which was once beautiful to behold because of its valleys and hills, its highlands, its shady trees and green plants, all of that is gone, all has returned to the realm of mortality. On that day, all people panic, running here and there to save themselves without direction or purpose, as mentioned in His word:

"On that Day people will be like scattered moths, and the mountains will be like wool, fluffed up." (al-Qari'ah/101: 4 and 5)

People ask each other what has happened to the earth, as mentioned in His word:

"And man will say, "What is [wrong] with it?" That Day, it will report its news because your Lord has inspired it." (az-Zalzalah/99: 3-4 and 5)
text.107:
After the mountains are pulverized and scattered by the wind in every direction, the places where the mountains stood become level, and the face of the earth, which was once beautiful to behold because of its valleys and hills, its highlands, its shady trees and green plants, is all gone. Everything has returned to the realm of annihilation. On that day, all people panic, running here and there to save themselves without direction or purpose, as mentioned in His word:

"On the Day when people will be like moths scattered about, and the mountains will be like wool, fluffed up." (al-Qari'ah/101: 4 and 5)

People ask each other what has happened to the earth, as mentioned in His word:

"And man will say, "What is [wrong] with it?" That Day, it will report its news because your Lord has inspired it." (az-Zalzalah/99: 3-4 and 5)
text.108:
In that chaotic and panicked atmosphere, they heard the voice of a caller, an angel, who drew their attention completely, and unknowingly they submitted and obediently followed the caller's command without further thought about the consequences of that command, as stated in Allah's word:

"Hastening towards the caller. The disbelievers will say, "This is a difficult Day." (al-Qamar/54: 8)

They were all summoned to appear before the presence of Allah, the Almighty and All-Powerful, to receive the reckoning of their deeds during their life in the world. No one could avoid or escape that reckoning. At that time, all creatures were silent; no sound was heard except whispers among themselves. No one dared to raise their voice because of the awesomeness of the atmosphere at that time, the atmosphere of facing the presence of Allah to receive the reckoning. Whoever believed and did good deeds will certainly receive manifold rewards and will be admitted into Paradise, and whoever disbelieved and had many sins will receive a fitting recompense and will be thrown into Hell.
text.109:
On that Day, no one will be able to help another or intercede for them, whether from angels or humans, except for those who have been granted permission by Allah to give intercession, and whose intercession is also accepted by Allah, in accordance with the verse:

"And how many angels there are in the heavens whose intercession is of no avail except after Allah has permitted [it] for whom He wills and approves." (an-Najm/53: 26)

Even angels, who are sinless, will not have their intercession accepted to help anyone at that time without Allah's permission, let alone devils, idols, or other polytheistic leaders. Surely, they will not be able to help their followers in the slightest. They are powerless to help themselves, let alone help others.
text.110: In this verse, Allah explains the reasons why intercession (syafaat) is not beneficial except with His permission. These reasons are because Allah knows all the deeds of mankind, their faith and disbelief, and nothing is hidden from Him. He is the one who can truly determine whether someone deserves intercession, based on their faith and deeds during their life in the world, and He is also the one who has the right and can determine that someone cannot be given intercession because of their disbelief and unforgivable sins. Whereas the angels or humans who have been permitted by Him to give intercession do not know this in detail.
text.111: At that time, all faces will be humbled, feeling submissive before Allah, the Almighty and the All-Powerful, Who will give the final judgment regarding the fate of each of them according to their faith and deeds, a judgment from the Most Just that cannot be disputed or denied and must be carried out. At that time, the disbelievers and sinners will regret why they followed the will of Satan and their desires in the world, prioritizing worldly matters without paying any attention to the fact that they would meet the Day of Reckoning, insulting and mocking the calls of the prophets and messengers for their happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.112: Those who believe and do righteous deeds as preparation for facing this Day of Reckoning, they feel happy and grateful, and the reward that Allah will bestow upon them according to His promise, according to His justice and mercy, is envisioned in their minds. They are completely certain that they will not be wronged, not even slightly harmed, and they will be admitted into the Garden of Delight (Jannatun Na'im) in which there are endless blessings and pleasures.
text.113:
This verse explains that Allah revealed the Qur'an in Arabic so that it would be easily understood by the polytheists of Mecca and so that they would be interested in paying attention to its contents and the teachings contained within it. Thus, they are expected to return to the truth and abandon misleading beliefs such as worshipping idols, and be able to live peacefully and happily by implementing the regulations contained within it, because all the commands and prohibitions within it are solely for the good and happiness of mankind in this world and the hereafter.

In the Qur'an, there are also several warnings and threats to the disobedient who do not want to heed the calls of the prophets and messengers, even rejecting them because they contradict the desires of their lusts, such as the stories of previous peoples who were destroyed because of their disobedience and information regarding the fate of the disbelievers and sinners in the hereafter. To return the Arabs, who were so hard-hearted and deeply rooted in shirk and their beliefs, to the truth, it is not enough with just da'wah and explanation, but the da'wah and explanation must also be accompanied by warnings and threats. This does not only apply to the polytheists of Mecca but also applies to all of mankind.

If da'wah and explanation are still not beneficial, then the time comes to give warnings by explaining historical facts and examples of previous peoples, the disasters and calamities that occurred in society due to moral corruption and the destruction of the norms of justice and truth. Thus, it can be hoped that people will become aware and conscious, become people who are pious to Allah, acknowledging His greatness and power, submitting to the regulations He has made for the benefit of mankind.
text.114:
It is narrated that when the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, was being recited some verses that were revealed to him by Jibril (Gabriel), he would quickly repeat them even before Jibril had finished reciting the entire verse that was to be conveyed to the Prophet. This was because the Prophet was afraid that if he didn't repeat it quickly, he might forget and not be able to remember it again. Therefore, Allah forbade him from acting like that, because such actions might further confuse his memorization. While he was repeating what had been recited to him, his attention was focused on repeating the recitation, not on the subsequent verses that Jibril would recite. Allah guarantees to preserve the Qur'an in the best possible way, so it is impossible for Prophet Muhammad to forget or be made to forget by Allah if he listened carefully first to all the verses that Jibril recited. Only after Jibril had finished reciting everything should the Prophet repeat it.

This verse affirms that Allah, the Most High, the Most Great, is Vast in His Knowledge, and with His Knowledge, He regulates everything and makes regulations that are in accordance with the interests of His creation, including regulations for the safety and happiness of mankind. He is the One who sent the prophets and messengers and revealed the holy books such as Zabur (Psalms), Torah, and Injil (Gospel), and He is also the One who revealed the Qur'an to Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. The Qur'an was revealed to Prophet Muhammad gradually, not all at once, in accordance with His wisdom. Sometimes only a few short verses or a short surah would be revealed, and sometimes long verses would be revealed according to the needs and requirements at that time.

Regarding this matter, Allah says:

"Move not your tongue concerning the (Qur'an) to make haste therewith. It is for Us to collect it and to make it clear. And when We have recited it to you, then follow its recital. Then surely it is for Us to explain it." (al-Qiyamah/75: 16-19)

Regarding Allah's guarantee and the preservation of the Qur'an, it is mentioned in the verse:

"Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an and indeed, We will be its guardian." (al-Hijr/15: 9)

Then Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, to pray that He would grant him an increase in knowledge. It is narrated by at-Tirmizi from Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah prayed as follows:

"O Allah, make the knowledge that You have taught me beneficial for me, teach me knowledge that is useful for me, and grant me an increase in knowledge. All praise is due to Allah in all circumstances, and I seek refuge in Allah from the state and all the actions of the inhabitants of Hell." (at-Tirmidzi, Ibnu Majah and al-Bazzar)
text.115: In this verse, Allah has explained that He entrusted Adam to always be wary of Iblis, who is his enemy and the enemy of his wife, Hawa (Eve). Indeed, Iblis had deceived them with his enticements, telling them that the tree of eternity (khuldi) was the best tree, and whoever ate its fruit would surely be eternal in Paradise. Because of his great desire to be eternal in Paradise, enjoying Allah's endless blessings, Adam forgot Allah's trust and His prohibition against eating the fruit of khuldi. Adam forgot that Iblis was his enemy who wanted to plunge him into the valley of sin. Adam forgot that Allah forbade him from eating the forbidden fruit, so he ate it. Here it is evident that Adam, who already had knowledge of Iblis's evil intentions, could still be deceived by the attractive promises that Iblis presented to him, let alone ordinary humans. Therefore, a person must have a strong will and an unwavering determination to not be influenced by anyone or any promise. He must always remember and be vigilant, and fiercely defend his stance and beliefs so that he cannot be tempted by Iblis.
text.116:
As a detailed explanation regarding Adam's deception by Iblis, leading him to eat the forbidden fruit, Allah explains the story from the beginning, namely when He commanded the angels to prostrate to Adam. Obediently and dutifully, the angels prostrated to Him without objection, without envy in their hearts, without any feelings of arrogance or pride, and without the slightest reluctance to carry out their Lord's command. This was in contrast to Iblis, who was arrogant and proud. He refused and did not want to prostrate to Adam because he considered himself higher and more noble than Adam. Why should he prostrate to Adam when Adam should be the one prostrating to him? This is mentioned in Allah's words:

"So the angels prostrated - all of them entirely. Except for Iblis; he was arrogant and became among the disbelievers." (Allah) said, "O Iblis, what prevented you from prostrating to that which I created with My hands? Were you arrogant [then], or were you [already] among the haughty?" He said, "I am better than him. You created me from fire and created him from clay." (Shad/38: 73-76)
text.117: Because Iblis refused to prostrate to Adam due to his arrogance and envy of the glory and honor bestowed upon Adam. Allah affirmed to him that Iblis was his enemy and the enemy of his wife. Therefore, he must be careful and vigilant regarding his actions, and never follow his enticements, which may come in the form of advice or suggestions. Iblis has no other goal than to inflict misfortune or disaster upon him. If he is deceived by his sweet words, which if followed, might cause Adam to be expelled from the Paradise full of His mercy and grace. If this happens, Iblis would laugh joyfully, while Adam would suffer a difficult life in the world, where he would have to struggle and work hard for his survival, whereas in Paradise, he lived in abundance, lacking nothing, and all his desires were easily achieved and fulfilled.
text.118:
Allah promised Adam that while in Paradise, he would not feel hungry or thirsty because various delicious foods, diverse drinks, and fruits would always be provided for him. He would never feel thirsty because a variety of delicious drinks were also provided for him, and he would not be exposed to the scorching sun because he would always be in a shady place with a gentle, moist breeze. He would not be naked because Allah had given him very good and beautiful clothes. Everything that is pleasing and desirable can be enjoyed in Paradise, as in His saying:

"We are your protectors in this worldly life and in the Hereafter. There you will have whatever your souls desire, and there you will have whatever you ask for. As hospitality from Allah, the All-Forgiving, Most Merciful." (Fushshilat/41: 31-32)

And His saying:

"And therein is whatever the souls desire and [what] delights the eyes." (az-Zukhruf/43: 71)
text.119: After Iblis saw how happy Adam and his wife were in paradise, enjoying various divine blessings, envy and jealousy arose in his heart, and he desperately wanted the blessings and favors bestowed by Allah to be immediately taken away from them. He saw no more appropriate and powerful way to realize this desire than to tempt them to eat the forbidden fruit of eternity (khuldi). By doing so, Allah would surely be angry with Adam and expel him from paradise for violating His command. Then Iblis approached Adam, pretending to be a loyal friend who always prioritized his well-being and happiness, and told him that the tree of eternity (khuldi) was a special tree, its fruit was extremely delicious, and there was no fruit in paradise more delicious than the fruit of eternity (khuldi). Whoever ate it would surely live forever and remain in paradise forever. If Adam wanted to remain in this paradise forever, then he had to eat the fruit, and he would surely live forever in a paradise that would never crumble.
text.120: This verse explains the situation of Adam and his wife Eve, when Iblis seduced them. Without remembering God's trust that Iblis was an enemy who wanted to harm them and that Allah had forbidden them from eating the forbidden fruit, Adam and Eve picked the fruit and immediately ate it with the hope that he and his wife would live forever in paradise. Not long after Adam and Eve ate the forbidden fruit, their private parts were exposed, even though before eating the forbidden fruit they had no attention whatsoever to their private parts. Then they felt ashamed and quickly picked leaves in paradise to cover themselves. Some commentators are of the opinion that as a result of eating the fruit of eternity (khuldi), sexual urges (instincts) arose in Adam and Eve, which is why they felt ashamed to see each other's private parts. Thus, driven by intense desire, Adam forgot God's trust until he violated His command. He failed to face his Lord's test, his determination and will weakened due to the temptation of Iblis and the temptation of his own desires and lusts, causing him to fall into the abyss of transgression.
text.121:
After realizing that he and his wife had violated Allah's command by eating the forbidden fruit, he regretted his transgression, felt disappointed for believing Iblis's enticements, and was deceived by the sweet words of his enemy. He was very worried about his fate with his wife because they had disobeyed their Lord. He felt guilty and asked for forgiveness for his mistake, as stated in the verse:

They said, "Our Lord, we have wronged ourselves, and if You do not forgive us and have mercy upon us, we will surely be among the losers." (al-A'raf/7: 23)
text.122:
God is Most Gracious and Most Merciful towards His servants, especially towards those who are appointed as caliphs on earth. Therefore, God would not retaliate against Adam's transgression of eating the forbidden fruit by inflicting punishment upon him, as he was in a state of forgetfulness and was deceived by the enticements of his enemy. Even though Adam had violated God's prohibition, which had commanded him not to be deceived by Satan, his enemy, Adam was expelled from Paradise. Adam and his wife deeply regretted their actions and repented, seeking forgiveness from Him. Therefore, God forgave his sin and chose him to be close to Him. As a result of violating God's command, Adam was ordered to leave Paradise and descend to earth, thus fulfilling God's decree that Adam would be made a Caliph on earth, as mentioned in His word:

"Indeed, I will make upon the earth a successive authority." (al-Baqarah/2: 30)
text.123:
It was not only Adam who had to descend to Earth, but also Iblis, the enemy who deceived him, had to descend to the world. These two types of creatures would become enemies of each other, Iblis's enmity towards humans is an eternal and continuous enmity until the Day of Judgment. Iblis will always try to mislead humans from the right path with various kinds of deceptions. Therefore, Allah reminds Adam's descendants to always be vigilant against their main enemy. When guidance has come from the Lord through His prophets and messengers, then humans should follow the guidance as taught by the messenger. By doing so, they will not be misguided and will not be miserable. Ibn Abbas said regarding this verse that Allah protects those who follow the teachings of the Al-Qur'an from misguidance in the world and from misfortune and disaster in the Hereafter.

From Ibn Abbas r.a., the Messenger of Allah said, "Whoever follows the Book of Allah, Allah will give him guidance to avoid misguidance in the world and protect him from the evil of reckoning on the Day of Judgment." (Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah and ath-Thabrani)
text.124:
Allah explains that those who turn away from the teachings of the Qur'an, disregard them, and oppose the guidance contained within, will, as a punishment, always live in hardship and difficulty. They will always be hesitant and restless, even if they possess wealth, rank, and position, because they are constantly disturbed by unfounded thoughts and fantasies regarding their wealth and position. They will always be haunted by the specter of losing the pleasures they have achieved, leading them to commit actions that cause hatred and harm in their society. Then, in the Hereafter, Allah will gather them with other people in a state of blindness of the heart. Just as in the world they always rejected Allah's clear guidance and squinted their eyes so that the guidance would not be seen by them, thus prolonging their straying, so too in the Hereafter they will not be able to see any reason to defend themselves from the decree of Allah, the Most Just.

Some commentators (mufassirun) say that those who turn away from Allah's teachings will indeed become blind in their physical senses, unable to see anything, as an additional punishment upon them. A person who is blind when chaos and disaster occur will be even more confused because they do not know what to do and have no direction to go to save themselves because they cannot see where the threatening danger is coming from. But after that, their eyes will become clear again because they will see for themselves the record of their deeds and how terrible and dreadful the punishment of Hell is, as mentioned in the verse:

"And the criminals will see the Fire and will be certain that they are to fall therein. And they will not find from it a way to turn away." (al-Kahf/18: 53)
text.125: Those who disbelieve will ask Allah, "Why did You make me blind, when I used to see clearly?" Allah will answer, "That is indeed so! Because in the world, when messengers came to you bringing His guidance, you turned away from it as if your eyes were blind, and as if you had forgotten it because you did not heed and pay attention to it." Therefore, Allah has made the eyes of your heart blind on the Day of Judgment, so that you cannot present any excuse to defend yourself from the punishment that has been prepared for you as a reward for your blindness during the world.
text.126: Those who disbelieve will ask Allah, "Why did You make me blind, when my eyes could see clearly before?" Allah will answer, "That is indeed so! Because in the world, when messengers came to you bringing His guidance, you turned away from it as if your eyes were blind, and as if you had forgotten it because you did not heed and pay attention to it." Therefore, Allah has made the eyes of your heart blind on the Day of Judgment, so that you cannot present any excuse to defend yourself from the torment that has been prepared for you as a recompense for your blindness during the world.
text.127:
Thus does Allah recompense those who transgress and do not believe in the proofs of His power. In this world, they encounter various difficulties, always hesitant and anxious, because they have no anchor in their lives except wealth, rank, and position. When afflicted with hardship or danger, they immediately panic and do not know what to do, and sometimes, without realizing it, they do things that harm themselves. They never experience peace and tranquility of heart. This means they never experience true happiness.

In the Hereafter, they will be punished with various torments, including torment of the heart because the eyes of their hearts have become blind, unable to provide reasons or *hujjah-hujjah* (arguments) to free themselves from Allah's punishment, or they are indeed made truly blind in their eyes so that they are even more tormented because they are completely powerless to overcome the atmosphere of chaos and terror. Indeed, the punishment in the Hereafter is far more severe and terrible, especially the punishment in Hell, which is eternal forever.
text.128:
In these verses, Allah calls the attention of the disbelievers to calmly contemplate the fate of past nations. They were destroyed by Allah due to their disbelief, through the descent of various calamities, some in the form of hurricanes, devastating earthquakes, and others in the form of loud, thunderous sounds. They can see with their own eyes the remnants left behind by those perished nations. These remnants show that they were strong and prosperous nations in their time, possessing large and sturdy buildings, and a higher culture than what the disbelievers of Mecca possessed. But because of their denial and disobedience, they were destroyed by Allah in the blink of an eye, with no one spared from the calamity. What can be seen now are only the ruins of their former palaces and fortresses.

The polytheists of Mecca, in their trading journeys during the summer and winter, pass through the ruins of those collapsed kingdoms, but they never think about why those kingdoms were destroyed and vanished, and they consider it merely the result of natural disasters. They should have been able to learn from the past nations and realize that no matter how strong and prosperous a nation is, if Allah wills their destruction because of their disobedience and disbelief, no one can defend or protect them. Why doesn't all of this attract their attention? Actually, if they were willing to think, there are many lessons and proofs of Allah's power found in those destroyed nations, but strangely, they do not heed them.
text.129:
If not for the mercy and compassion of Allah, or because of His decree that the disbelieving community of Muhammad (peace be upon him) would not be destroyed like previous communities, and that the recompense for their disbelief would be postponed until the Day of Judgment, they would surely have experienced destruction as well. This is mentioned in His saying:

"Nay, the Hour is their promised time (for their full recompense), and the Hour will be more grievous and more bitter." (al-Qamar/54: 46)

The Ulama say that the wisdom behind postponing the punishment of the disobedient community of Muhammad (peace be upon him) until the Day of Judgment is to give them an opportunity to repent, or for some of their descendants to believe. This is an honor and a glory for the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and a mercy and compassion from Allah towards his community, so that the followers of his teachings will increase in number. This is in accordance with his hope, as mentioned in his saying narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abi Hurairah:

"What has been given to me is revelation that Allah has revealed to me. So I hope that I will be the Prophet with the most followers among the Prophets." (Riwayat asy-Syaikhan)
text.130:
Then Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to remain patient in the face of the actions of his disbelieving people, as well as their mockery and insults towards him, such as accusing him of being a sorcerer, a madman, a poet, and so on. In addition to that, he should constantly remember and sanctify his Lord by glorifying Him (tasbih) and praying before sunrise, before sunset, and in the middle of the night. Indeed, by remembering Allah and through prayer, a person can free himself from mental confusion, sadness, and doubt. Prophet Muhammad himself once said about the benefit of prayer in calming his heart:

"And my heart finds tranquility in prayer." (Narrated by Ahmad and an-Nasai from al-Mugirah)

In another verse, Allah commands that to overcome a difficult problem, we should be patient and establish prayer.

"And seek help through patience and prayer, and indeed, it is difficult except for the humbly submissive [to Allah]." (al-Baqarah/2: 45)

In a hadith narrated by Ibn Jarir, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Verily, you will see your Lord as you see this moon, and you will not be hindered in seeing Him. If you are able to strive so that you are not overcome by sleep before sunrise and before sunset, then do so." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Then the Prophet recited this verse 130.

It is narrated from Abu Hurairah. Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "Allah says, 'O son of Adam, devote your time to worshiping Me, and I will fill your heart with richness (inner wealth) and remove your poverty. But if you do not do so, I will fill your heart with preoccupation and will not remove your poverty.'" (Narrated by Ahmad and at-Tirmidzi)

Then Allah said to Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), if you have done what I have commanded you, namely prayer before sunrise, before sunset, and in the middle of the night, then your soul will be peaceful and tranquil, and you will be pleased with what Allah has bestowed upon you, as mentioned in the verse:

"And your Lord is going to give you, and you will be satisfied." (adh-Dhuha/93: 5)

Regarding this inner contentment and satisfaction, a sahih hadith reveals the following:

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "Allah says to the inhabitants of Paradise, 'O inhabitants of Paradise.' They reply, 'We are ready to listen to Your command, O our Lord, blessed and happy are You.' Then Allah says, 'Are you pleased and satisfied?' They reply, 'How could we not be pleased and satisfied? You have bestowed upon us blessings that You have not given to anyone else among Your creation.' Then Allah says, 'I will bestow upon you something better than that.' They ask, 'What is that, O our Lord, that is better than the blessings we have received?' Allah says, Allah says, 'I will bestow upon you My pleasure, and I will never be angry with you after that, forever.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Such is the case when a person has attained the pleasure of Allah thanks to his obedience and submission to his Lord.
text.131:
This verse explains that in order to strengthen the Prophet's heart and solidify his resolve in facing the struggle to uphold the word of Allah, Allah commanded him not to turn his attention to the pleasures, luxuries, and wealth enjoyed by some disbelievers. This is because it would weaken his spirit if his eyes were dazzled by the glitter of worldly adornments and he desired to possess what the rich possessed. All the blessings given to the disbelievers are only temporary, like a flower in bloom, but soon the fragrant flower will wither and its leaves will fall one by one, and all its beauty and appeal will disappear. The blessing of wealth given to the disbelievers is only temporary, as a test for them, whether with that blessing of God they will be grateful to Him by believing and using it to achieve His pleasure, or whether they will remain disbelievers and become more deeply immersed in error, so that the wealth becomes the cause of their own misfortune. Allah has bestowed upon the Prophet, in place of those outward blessings, a better blessing, namely peace of mind and happiness in the form of divine pleasure.

It was narrated by Abu Rafi', a guest came to visit the Messenger of Allah, while there was nothing in his house worthy to be offered to the guest. The Messenger of Allah ordered me to borrow a little wheat flour from a Jew and it would be paid later in the month of Rajab. The Jew refused to lend it except with a guarantee. I returned to the Messenger of Allah to report this. The Messenger of Allah said:

"By Allah, I am trustworthy among the inhabitants of the heavens and trustworthy among the inhabitants of the earth. If he lent to me or sold to me, I would certainly pay him. Take my coat of mail." (Narrated by al-Bazzar).

Then this verse was revealed (Taha/20: 131).
text.132:
This verse explains the next mandate, which is no less important than the previous command, namely Allah's command to the Prophet (peace be upon him) to instruct his family to perform prayer (salat) and to be patient in performing prayer by maintaining its timing and continuity. This command is accompanied by a second command, which is a reminder that Allah does not ask the Prophet for sustenance; on the contrary, Allah will provide him with sustenance, so the Prophet does not need to worry about the sustenance of his family. Therefore, his family should not be influenced or blinded by the wealth and pleasures possessed by the wives of the disbelievers. Such is Allah's mandate to His Messenger as provision for facing a difficult struggle, which should serve as an example for every fighter who wants to uphold the truth on earth. They must first establish a close relationship with their Creator by consistently performing prayer and strengthening their inner selves with the qualities of steadfastness and patience. In addition, all members of his household should possess the same qualities as him. Thus, he will be steadfast in his struggle, not swayed by the adornments of worldly life such as wealth, rank, and position.

These are the mandates practiced by the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and his companions, so they were truly successful in their struggle, so that in a period of approximately 23 years, Islam had developed rapidly throughout the Arabian Peninsula, and the word of Allah became the highest and most noble word.

If the Messenger and his family faced various difficulties, he would invite his family to pray, as narrated from Thabit, who said:

When the Prophet's family was afflicted with hardship, he would command them, "Come, pray, pray." Thabit said, "The prophets, when afflicted with hardship, would immediately perform prayer." (Riwayat Ibnu Abi Hatim)
text.133:
The disbelievers of Mecca mocked Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), saying that his call to the religion he brought was utter nonsense. If the religion he brought was true, then he should prove it with miracles like those given to Prophet Saleh, namely the she-camel, those given to Prophet Musa, such as the staff, and those given to Isa, which were raising the dead and healing leprosy. If they had even a little willingness to think and a tendency to accept the truth, they would not have uttered such words, because the Qur'an itself, which was revealed to Prophet Muhammad, is his greatest miracle among the miracles given to the Prophets before Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon them all).

Various pieces of evidence have shown that they cannot imitate the beauty of the Qur'an's sentence structure and vocabulary, nor can they bring even a short Surah that is equal in *balagah* and *fashahah* to the Surahs in the Qur'an. Isn't it true that in the Qur'an there are stories about past communities, while Prophet Muhammad himself did not know those stories beforehand? Isn't it true that in the Qur'an there are *shariahs* and regulations whose purpose and objective are the same as the *shariahs* brought by the Prophets before, namely *shariahs* for the benefit and happiness of mankind in this world and the hereafter? In fact, the Qur'an alone is sufficient as proof of the truth of Muhammad (peace be upon him) and is sufficient as a great miracle that is eternal and everlasting. Allah greatly regrets their attitude of rejecting the Qur'an outright without any valid reason and not wanting to think about it even a little. In another verse, Allah also says:

"Nay, but they are clear signs in the breasts of those who have been granted knowledge, and none but the unjust deny Our signs. And they say: "Why are not signs sent down to him from his Lord?" Say: "The signs are only with Allah, and I am only a plain warner." Is it not enough for them that We have sent down to you the Book (the Qur'an) which is recited to them? Verily, therein is mercy and reminder for a people who believe." (al-'Ankabut/29: 49-51)
text.134: This verse explains that if Allah had destroyed them before sending Prophet Muhammad to them, they would have said on the Day of Judgment that Allah did not send them a messenger whose teachings they could follow so that they would become believers before facing this Day of Reckoning. Therefore, Allah did not destroy them like previous nations so that they would have no excuse when facing the Day of Reckoning on the Day of Judgment. Because Allah has sent them a messenger who will explain to them the verses of Allah. Then it is up to them whether they will follow the guidance of Allah or whether they will remain in disbelief and constantly insult and mock Muhammad, peace be upon him (saw).
text.135:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (saw) to say to the disbelievers of Mecca, as an answer to their various excuses and mockery of him, that if they do not want to accept Allah's guidance and remain in disbelief and disobedience, then the Messenger of Allah, along with them, will await Allah's judgment on the Day of Judgment. Surely they will know who is on the right path and who is guided. They will know that they are the ones who are misguided and will be thrown into Hell. This is mentioned in Allah's words:

"And they will know, when they see the punishment, who is farther astray in the way." (al-Furqan/25: 42)

And His words:

"They will know tomorrow who is the insolent liar." (al-Qamar/54: 26)
